dt.t: iron is a {wi}notorious{/wi} conductor of heat
an area {wi}notorious{/wi} for soot, smog, and dust

pt: {sc}famous{/sc} {sc}renowned{/sc} {sc}celebrated{/sc} {sc}noted{/sc} {sc}notorious{/sc} {sc}distinguished{/sc} {sc}eminent{/sc} {sc}illustrious{/sc} mean known far and wide. {sc}famous{/sc} implies little more than the fact of being, sometimes briefly, widely and popularly known.

pt.t: one of the most {it}renowned{/it} figures in sports history

pt: {sc}celebrated{/sc} implies notice and attention especially in print.

pt.t: the most {it}celebrated{/it} beauty of her day

pt: {sc}notorious{/sc} frequently adds to {sc}famous{/sc} an implication of questionableness or evil.

pt.t: a {it}distinguished{/it} scientist who won the Nobel Prize

pt: {sc}eminent{/sc} implies even greater prominence for outstanding quality or character.
{sc}illustrious{/sc} stresses enduring honor and glory attached to a deed or person.

et: Medieval Latin {it}notorius{/it}, from Late Latin {it}notorium{/it} information, indictment, from Latin {it}noscere{/it} to come to know {ma}{mat|know|}{/ma}
shortdef: generally known and talked of; especially : widely and unfavorably known

dt: {bc}as is notorious {bc}as is very well known

shortdef: as is notorious : as is very well known
